We now go on to furnish a body of practical suggestions on the study of history, collected out of a few standard authorities Instead of throw- ing these into the form of a brief abstract, we have judged it better to give the very words of the writers quoted. The passages in question are such as will repay frequent perusal. They have been selected with the view of opening the reader's eyes to the real nature of historical study-—its peculiar appropriateness at the present time—its disciplinal value—and its feasibility.
